title: Why the world needs another CMS
body:
Wait...what? Where's the directory I was just..? Oh, *shit*. I didn't. I couldn't have.... *Fuck*. I did. OK. Think. Backups? I keep everything under version control but...not the content. Did I make a copy of the content directory as recommended? *No*. Why would I? I've performed hundreds—if not *thousands*—of similar operations and not lost anything. Until *now*. 

OK, what else? *Think*. Cron job: automated backups of the DB. *Crap*. I didn't get around to setting that up. I was more concerned with the code. OK. How do you recover files deleted with `rm`? Maybe if that sector of the disk hasn't been overwritten, I can recover the directory I deleted...

### Oh my word!

In December of 2015 I had an idea for a tool that'll allow me to catalogue my favourite words. I knocked together a Chrome extension in an afternoon and was pleased with the return on investment. It was basic, but effective. About a month later, the extension supported multiple users and had an accompanying mobile app and a [website](https://ohmyword.xyz).

The main site was actually a purpose-built Node application, and the [blog](https://ohmyword.xyz/inspiration/) *was* powered by [Ghost](https://tryghost.com).

### Ghost

I'd been aware of Ghost since the Kickstarter campaign. I started using it as soon as it became available. Even with its limited feature set, I was immediately a fan. It felt so refreshing after spending so much time with Wordpress. Besides the excellent decision to provide a Markdown editor, it generally felt lighter, faster and less cluttered than the dreaded *'press*.

### Wordpress

When I first discovered Wordpress, I'll admit, I was somewhat enamoured. At the time I was coming from Joomla and, even though I was already a PHP developer by[1] that point, I just couldn't get into it.

Wordpress was *easy* to get into. It had a user-friendly interface, a vast number of plugins and themes available, and it was incredibly easy to extend it, if you had even a modicum of know-how. Even though it  was originally just a blogging platform, you could—and still can—build practically any kind of website with it.

I spent years working with Wordpress, both professionally and in my spare time, but never more intensely than while working on Rough Guides. It uses a mix of third-party, in-house and hybrid plugins, as well as significant amounts of custom functionality that sits outside of plugins. The site gets millions of visitors every month

[1]:http://www.com.com
